This relief will help millions of Americans pay off their loans and get on with their lives. Sign up for more announcements here: https://www.ed.gov/subscriptions

What’s more, your loan balance won’t grow as long as you keep making monthly payments. An updated income-driven repayment program will shield low-income borrowers from making any payments, and will cap everybody else's at 5% of their annual income.

That debt forgiveness doubles to $20K if you’ve ever received a Pell Grant.  
 
Monthly payments have been suspended through December 31, 2022, extending the pandemic pause on student loan payments and interest accrual.

Federal student loan holders – including grad PLUS & Parent PLUS borrowers - who make less than $125k, or $250k for families (based on your 2020 or 2021 income), can get up to $10k forgiven. If the Dept of Ed already has your income on file, you’ll get relief automatically.

We are committed to defending women’s rights, freedoms and rightful place at the decision-making table.
 
Because we know this truth: when women succeed, America succeeds.
 
Read my full statement on Women’s Equality Day: https://www.speaker.gov/newsroom/82622

Today, @HouseDemocrats are mobilizing for a Day of Action across the nation: a growing drumbeat of fierce opposition to these right-wing attacks. While Republicans seek to turn back the clock for women, House Democrats will never relent in our fight to put #PeopleOverPolitics.

Unwavering in our commitment to reproductive justice, the Democratic House has passed landmark legislation to enshrine the protections of Roe v. Wade into law, establish a federal right to use birth control and reaffirm Americans’ right to access health care across state lines.

As we celebrate this triumph in our history, women’s most basic rights and dignities remain under assault.
 
In the wake of the heart-wrenching Dobbs decision, Republicans have waged a dark crusade of punishment and control – even seeking to impose a national abortion ban.
Today, American women proudly carry on the spirit of the heroes who came before us: marching in the streets, organizing in our communities and legislating in the halls of power.

Too often unsung in the American story, courageous women of color continued advancing that struggle for decades after – moving us ever closer to realizing our founding promise of liberty and justice for all.
In winning the right to vote more than a century ago, trailblazing suffragists tore down a seemingly immovable barrier to women’s full and equal citizenship in our Democracy.

Today, the American people mark the 102nd anniversary of the 19th Amendment: a hard-won victory secured by generations of women bravely fighting to build a more perfect union. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FbFwF9xWYAAyI1l.jpg

Together, we need to step up and fight to regain our reproductive rights. I don’t want to have fewer rights than my mother and grandmother did and I certainly don’t want to leave fewer rights for the next generation.

That’s why I introduced the My Body, My Data Act to protect our reproductive rights and digital privacy. We have so much information online – whether it’s in period or fertility apps or even Google searches – but that doesn’t mean it should be able to be weaponized against us.

In the House, we’ve passed legislation to protect the right to an abortion and contraception, and protections for those who cross state lines to access abortion care. But we can’t stop there. Because the post-Roe era won’t look like the pre-Roe era.

If you do not see the difference between these two things, you have either not done your research or are propagating lies to sugarcoat what the Biden Administration is doing.
Granted, the PPP loan forgiveness program was abused in some cases, but these two things are unequivocally different. Period. It’s comparing apples and oranges.
3) PPP loans were intended to be forgiven. A student loan was meant to be paid over time by the borrower. In both cases, those were the terms of the promissory note.

2) PPP gave businesses money after the government forced them to shut their businesses down and their employees couldn’t go to work. Student loan “forgiveness” transfers a debt the borrower voluntarily agreed to pay to an unwilling party (the American taxpayer).

1) PPP loans were legally authorized and funded by Congress and signed into law by the President. Student loan “forgiveness” was unilaterally enacted by President Biden using the HEROES Act (intended for our service members).
To those gaslighting Republicans about PPP loans and student loan forgiveness, let me give you a few reasons why these two things are completely different: A thread.
